concepts.name: Ficus Elastica
concepts.explanation: The scientific name for the Rubber Tree plant, a popular indoor plant known for its glossy, rubbery leaves.

concepts.name: Rubber Tree Varieties
concepts.explanation: Ficus elastica is the most common species, but there are different cultivars with variations in leaf color and size.

concepts.name: Rubber Tree Light Requirements
concepts.explanation: Rubber Trees thrive in bright, indirect light. They can tolerate lower light conditions but may grow more slowly.

concepts.name: Watering Rubber Trees
concepts.explanation: Rubber Trees prefer to dry out slightly between waterings. Water thoroughly when the top inch or two of soil is dry.

concepts.name: Rubber Tree Soil
concepts.explanation: Well-draining, peat-based potting soil is suitable for Rubber Trees. They appreciate soil that retains some moisture.

concepts.name: Repotting Rubber Trees
concepts.explanation: Repot Rubber Trees when they outgrow their containers or become root-bound. Choose a slightly larger pot and refresh the soil.

concepts.name: Rubber Tree Propagation
concepts.explanation: Rubber Trees can be propagated through stem cuttings. These cuttings can develop into new plants with proper care.

concepts.name: Fertilizing Rubber Trees
concepts.explanation: Fertilize Rubber Trees sparingly during the growing season (spring and summer) with a balanced, diluted liquid fertilizer.

concepts.name: Common Rubber Tree Pests
concepts.explanation: Rubber Trees are relatively pest-resistant, but occasional pests like mealybugs or spider mites may appear. Regular inspection is advisable.

concepts.name: Rubber Tree Benefits
concepts.explanation: Besides their decorative value, Rubber Trees are known for their air-purifying qualities, helping to improve indoor air quality.

concepts.name: Rubber Tree Growth Habit
concepts.explanation: Rubber Trees have an upright growth habit with glossy, broad leaves that give them a tropical appearance.

concepts.name: Temperature Tolerance
concepts.explanation: Rubber Trees prefer indoor temperatures between 65-80°F (18-27°C). They are sensitive to cold drafts and frost.

concepts.name: Rubber Tree Flowering
concepts.explanation: Mature Rubber Trees can produce small, inconspicuous flowers, but their primary appeal lies in their foliage.

concepts.name: Low Maintenance
concepts.explanation: Rubber Trees are considered low-maintenance indoor plants, requiring attention to soil moisture and occasional feeding.

concepts.name: Rubber Tree Toxicity
concepts.explanation: Rubber Trees are toxic if ingested and can cause stomach discomfort. Keep them out of reach of children and pets.

concepts.name: Origin of Rubber Trees
concepts.explanation: Rubber Trees are native to Southeast Asia, particularly regions in India, Nepal, Bhutan, Burma, and Malaysia.

concepts.name: Rubber Tree Lifespan
concepts.explanation: With proper care, Rubber Trees can have a long lifespan and persist for many years, becoming a focal point in homes and offices.

concepts.name: Decorative Uses
concepts.explanation: Rubber Trees are often used as elegant and decorative indoor plants, adding a touch of greenery to interior spaces.

concepts.name: Rubber Tree Care Tips
concepts.explanation: Tips and guidelines for maintaining a healthy and thriving Rubber Tree, including cleaning the leaves and avoiding overwatering.
